panels.description: System resources usage
panels.title: System resources overview

panels.description: Tracks the usage of disk space
panels.title: Disk usage

targets.expr:
sum(rocksdb_props{job="$job", name="rocksdb.block-cache-usage"}) + 
sum(rocksdb_props{job="$job", name="rocksdb.cur-size-all-mem-tables"}) + 
sum(rocksdb_props{job="$job", name="rocksdb.estimate-table-readers-mem"}) + 
sum(jvm_memory_committed_bytes{job="$job", instance=~"$instance", region="heap"}) + 
sum(jvm_memory_committed_bytes{job="$job", instance=~"$instance", region="non-heap"}) +
sum(jvm_memory_buffer_pool_capacity_bytes{job="$job", instance=~"$instance"}) +
sum(jvm_threads_total{job="$job"}) * 1048576

panels.description: Those we run if them are affected by blockchain updates
panels.title: Active requests

panels.description: Those we run if them are affected by blockchain updates
panels.title: Active requests

panels.description:
Tracks the system load average in 1m / 5m / 15m.

They indicate the average number of tasks (processes) wanting to run in the last 1m / 5m / 15m.

On Linux systems, these numbers is approximated and include processes wanting to run on the CPUs, as well as processes blocked in uninterruptible I/O (usually disk I/O).
This gives a high-level idea of resource load (or demand).

The three numbers give some idea of how load is changing over time.

Excellent post on the subject: http://www.brendangregg.com/blog/2017-08-08/linux-load-averages.html
panels.title: System load average

panels.description: Tracks ratio for failed network packets
panels.title: Retransmits

panels.description: Tracks the current time the CPU is busy on user mode.

targets.expr:
sum(rate(host_cpu_usage_sum{job="$job", instance=~"$instance", mode="user"}[$__interval]))
/
sum(rate(host_cpu_usage_count{job="$job", instance=~"$instance", mode="user"}[$__interval]))

panels.title: CPU %usr

panels.description: Tracks the current time the CPU is busy on system mode.

targets.expr:
sum(rate(host_cpu_usage_sum{job="$job", instance=~"$instance", mode="system"}[$__interval]))
/
sum(rate(host_cpu_usage_count{job="$job", instance=~"$instance", mode="system"}[$__interval]))

panels.title: CPU %system

panels.description:
Tracks the current time the CPU is stuck waiting for IO.

If this value is high, the disk might be the bottleneck.

targets.expr:
sum(rate(host_cpu_usage_sum{job="$job", instance=~"$instance", mode="wait"}[$__interval]))
/
sum(rate(host_cpu_usage_count{job="$job", instance=~"$instance", mode="wait"}[$__interval]))

panels.title: CPU %wait

panels.title: Network usage

panels.description: Tracks the current time the CPU is busy by the process in user mode.
panels.title: Proc %usr

panels.description: Tracks the current time the CPU is busy by the process in kernel mode.
panels.title: Proc %system

panels.description:
Tracks the current time the CPU is stolen by some process outside the VM.

If this value is high, it could be caused either by the supervisor is very busy, by a noisy neighbor or by some limitation on the quota assigned by the virtualization service.

targets.expr:
sum(rate(host_cpu_usage_sum{job="$job", instance=~"$instance", mode="stolen"}[$__interval]))
/
sum(rate(host_cpu_usage_count{job="$job", instance=~"$instance", mode="stolen"}[$__interval]))

panels.title: CPU %steal

panels.description: Tracks the number of file descriptors in used by the process.

panels.description: The average requests rate in the last $__interval across all selected instances stacked by status
panels.title: Throughput (avg. $__interval)

panels.description: Latency of requests with 2xx status response over $__interval
panels.title: Latency: only 2xx status response

panels.description:
Given:
  * Success requests: status 2xx
  * Valid requests: status 2xx or status 5xx

The uptime could be estimated by 'success requests' / 'valid requests'.

This is just an approximation because it doesn't take in account a lot of corner cases. For a more accurate metric it should be measured from outside the app.
panels.title: Approximated Uptime: 'requests with 2xx status response' / 'requests with 2xx or 5xx status response'

panels.description: Relative frequency distribution of response 2xx, 3xx, 4xx and 5xx over $__interval
panels.title: 2xx | 4xx | 3xx | 5xx % (avg. $__interval)

panels.description: Latency of requests with 3xx status response over $__interval
panels.title: Latency: only 3xx status response

panels.description: Latency of requests with 4xx status response over $__interval
panels.title: Latency: only 4xx status response

panels.description: Latency of requests with 5xx status response over $__interval
panels.title: Latency: only 5xx status response

panels.description: Either new or re-added again: ignored then added during a short period of time.
panels.title: Tracked requests

panels.description: Running scripts queue size
panels.title: Job scheduler size

panels.description: Users don't ask them again for some time
panels.title: Ignored requests

panels.description: How long a request is processed in the queue
panels.title: Time in queue

targets.expr: histogram_quantile(0.95, sum by(le, name) (rate(executor_time_in_queue_seconds_bucket{instance=~"$instance", job="$job", akka_system=""}[$__rate_interval])))
histogram_quantile(0.75, sum by(le, name) (rate(executor_time_in_queue_seconds_bucket{instance=~"$instance", job="$job", akka_system=""}[$__rate_interval])))

panels.description: pinned = can't be evicted
panels.title: RAM - Block Cache Usage

panels.description: Size of in-memory data structures where RocksDB writes new data first before flushing them to SST files on disk.
panels.title: RAM - MemTables

panels.description: FLUSH_WRITE_BYTES - how much bytes moved from WAL to SST during a flush
panels.title: WAL Written

panels.description: A new version is created for each successful commit of a write batch (or transaction). High numbers for this metric may indicate that your database has many pending writes, which could be due to a slow disk or high write volumes.
panels.title: Live versions

panels.description: Estimated amount of memory (RAM) used by table readers, excluding the block cache
panels.title: RAM - Table Readers / Index and Bloom Filters

panels.description: The observed false positive rate

targets.expr:
(sum(increase(rocksdb_stats{job="$job", name="BLOOM_FILTER_FULL_POSITIVE"}[1m])) - sum(increase(rocksdb_stats{job="$job", name="BLOOM_FILTER_FULL_TRUE_POSITIVE"}[1m]))) /
(sum(increase(rocksdb_stats{job="$job", name="BLOOM_FILTER_FULL_POSITIVE"}[1m])) - sum(increase(rocksdb_stats{job="$job", name="BLOOM_FILTER_FULL_TRUE_POSITIVE"}[1m])) + sum(increase(rocksdb_stats{job="$job", name="BLOOM_FILTER_USEFUL"}[1m])))

panels.title: Bloom filters - false positive rate

panels.description: The number of ... data block reads from cache.
panels.title: Block Cache Data

targets.expr: histogram_quantile(0.99, max by(le, method, service) (grpc_latency_seconds_bucket{job="$job", instance=~"$instance"}))

panels.description: If this number is high, you could want to relax a limit of concurrent connections on a frontend of gRPC server
panels.title: Blocked calls

panels.description: The average outgoing requests rate in the last $__interval across all selected instances
panels.title: Throughput of outgoing requests over $__interval

panels.description: Latency of outgoing requests in the last $__interval across all selected instances

targets.expr: histogram_quantile(0.99, sum by(le, span_kind) (rate(span_processing_time_seconds_bucket{job="$job", instance=~"$instance", error="false", operation="$client_operation"}[$__interval])))
histogram_quantile(0.99, sum by(le, span_kind) (rate(span_processing_time_seconds_bucket{job="$job", instance=~"$instance", error="true", operation="$client_operation"}[$__interval])))

panels.title: Latency of outgoing requests over $__interval

panels.description:
Tracks the system load average in 1m / 5m / 15m.

They indicate the average number of tasks (processes) wanting to run in the last 1m / 5m / 15m.

On Linux systems, these numbers is approximated and include processes wanting to run on the CPUs, as well as processes blocked in uninterruptible I/O (usually disk I/O).
This gives a high-level idea of resource load (or demand).

The three numbers give some idea of how load is changing over time.

Excellent post on the subject: http://www.brendangregg.com/blog/2017-08-08/linux-load-averages.html
panels.title: System load average in 1m / 5m / 15m

panels.description:
Tracks the hiccups detected in the VM (also known as idle jitters) measured in nanoseconds. The 90ht percentile is presented.

For more info: https://www.azul.com/jhiccup/
panels.title: VM Hiccups (or idle jitters) in nanoseconds (p90)

panels.description: Tracks the usage of CPU by the VM in the different typical views.

targets.expr:
rate(host_cpu_usage_sum{job="$job", instance=~"$instance", mode="user"}[$__interval])
/
rate(host_cpu_usage_count{job="$job", instance=~"$instance", mode="user"}[$__interval])

rate(host_cpu_usage_sum{job="$job", instance=~"$instance", mode="system"}[$__interval])
/
rate(host_cpu_usage_count{job="$job", instance=~"$instance", mode="system"}[$__interval])

rate(host_cpu_usage_sum{job="$job", instance=~"$instance", mode="wait"}[$__interval])
/
rate(host_cpu_usage_count{job="$job", instance=~"$instance", mode="wait"}[$__interval])

rate(host_cpu_usage_sum{job="$job", instance=~"$instance", mode="stolen"}[$__interval])
/
rate(host_cpu_usage_count{job="$job", instance=~"$instance", mode="stolen"}[$__interval])
